captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: What if every day
on your ride home from work,

you came across an old car or
truck that sparked your
imagination?

Well, if your name is Craig
Morrison of Art Morrison
Enterprises, you don't wait.
You go up and you buy it.

Then you take it home and you
fit it with a custom chassis,
suspension, and engine.

And you make it into
an unbelievable

Pro-Touring/Restomod
Hot Rod truck.

That's exactly what we have here
with this 1950 Chevrolet.

So this is "BIG MUSCLE."
Stay tuned.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CRAIG MORRISON: What we have
here is a 1950 Chevrolet 3100

pickup truck that we built at
Art Morrison Enterprises, to

showcase our new chassis for the
1947 to 1953 Chevy trucks.

The drivetrain of this
particular project truck that

we built is a GM performance
parts turn-key
HO 350 crate motor.

And from GM it comes complete
with the carburetor, air

cleaner, oil, and the oil pan,
a front drive system.

I mean, it's a really great,
complete package.

But we wanted to kind of play
with that a little bit.

And we put a new camshaft
and lifters to boost the
horsepower a little bit.

And then we used the vintage
air front runner set up, a

serpentine kit that kind of
packaged everything tight and
down in front of the engine.

And then used the Atomic EFI
from MSD, and that piece has

been just absolutely
phenomenal.

For transmission, we used the
Hughes Performance 4L60E
overdrive automatic.

And it is completely
controllable and programmable,

for as far as shift points,
and when you want the

converter to lock up and
all that sort of thing.

And then out back it's one of
our own manufactured nine-inch

Ford housings, with a strange
engineering third member, with

3.50 to 1 ring and pinion gear,
and what they call a
Truetrac, which is sort of--

instead of it being an actual
gear pack like limited-slip

differential, it uses gears so
it's not so harsh when it
locks and unlocks.
[ENGINE STARTING]
[ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: We get submissions
for "BIG MUSCLE" for just
about everything.

I mean, we've got endless
submissions coming in by

email, Facebook, and
everything else.

So when our buddy Craig Morrison
called us and said,

listen, we just built a really,
really cool 1950s

Chevy sport truck, we couldn't
turn it down.

You know, Craig and Art Morrison
build some of the

coolest and best custom chassis
in the business, and

we've known these guys
for a long time.

When they call you and they
offer up a car or truck to

you, you generally don't say
no for the simple fact that

it's going to be really,
really good.
And we know this.

So you may ask yourself, why
did Craig start with a 1950
Chevy pickup truck?

I mean, it's not really a super
hot rod style truck.

And it is to an extent, but it's
not really mainstream.
And the reason is this.

When Craig was a little kid, his
grandfather had a 1948 GMC

pickup that was very, very
similar to this truck.

And growing up out on a farm,
he was telling us stories

about when he would stand on
the running board at, like,
seven, eight years old.

And his grandfather would take
him up the path in the truck.

And I mean, it's those kind of
memories that make these cars

speak to you, which is
why we're driving
this truck here today.

So another reason that Craig
wanted to build a 1940s, '50s

truck, was that at Art Morrison
Enterprises, they had

just developed a
chassis for it.

And that is actually the
chassis that we're
riding on right now.

And basically what he wanted
to create was not a

Pro-Touring car, not a Restomod,
or any buzzword type

thing, but just a great chassis
that owners could

build upon and use as a base
to build a great hot rod.

CRAIG MORRISON: The kit that
we make for this truck, and

also all sorts of
other vehicles,
is a complete package.

All the front suspension, all
the rear suspension, the disc

brakes, the power rack, and
pinion steering, axles, third

member, basically is a complete
rolling chassis, just
less the tires and wheels.

For a bolt-on chassis like this
to go from the idea to a

finished product is probably
about a four- to five-month

process, where we'll pull the
chassis out from underneath

the cab, use what's called a
FaroArm to actually pick up

all the data points along the
chassis for engine mounts,

body mounts, bumper mounts, all
the critical mounts on the
chassis itself.

We'll then build a few test
chassis to see if they fit,

and how they work with the body,
and if they pick up all
the points that we need to.

From there, then we'll build
a jig to be able
to repeat that chassis.

And so it's quite an
involved process.

But overall it works out very
well for the company

MIKE MUSTO: If you would
describe this interior in one

word, it would have to
be this-- simplistic.

Everything you need and
nothing you don't.

The gauges tell you everything
from water temp, fuel, oil,

voltage, what you want to
know in a work truck.

The dash, you have a
radio in here, you
have climate control.

And it's done in such a way that
it's not overbearing on

the driver as far as kind of
sensory overload, like so many
vehicles are today.

I mean, you get in, like, a
Ford King Ranch right now,

you've got more bells
and whistles
than most luxury cars.

And it kind of takes
it away from the
feel of a pickup truck.

Sometimes there is no mistaking
that you're driving
a 60-year-old vehicle.

For instance, like visibility in
this thing is pretty awful.
I'm not going to lie to you.

I mean, the way that things are
done-- like the windshield

wipers, they come up, and they
cut off half your face.

So if I close my left eye, my
visibility is no better than

if I have it open because the
wipers, they only hit half the
windshield.

If you're trying to pass
somebody and you look over

your left shoulder to see
something, you're not going to

because there's a blind spot
that's bigger than Roseanne

Barr's ass, and you can't
see anything.

So what you actually have to
do is lean back, look over

your shoulder, and then see if
there's somebody behind you.

It's actually incredible that
any of these trucks survived

the last 60 years without
getting wrapped into a pole.

One of the best parts about guys
like Craig is he drives
this truck.

In fact, this truck is
his daily driver.

The other thing is, you can see
it's crappy weather out.

So when we called Craig and
we're like, dude, it's lousy
weather out.
His answer was simple.
He said, so?
That's what we want to hear.

A lot of guys will not take
their cars out, or their

trucks out, or whatever
vehicle they
have if it's raining.
And guys, it's a car.
It's a truck.
It's going to get wet.

It does when you put the
flipping hose on it.

Don't worry about
a little rain.

Take the cars out and drive
them and enjoy them.

CRAIG MORRISON: It is kind of
tough to compare the numbers

as far as the testing that we
did just recently with "Custom

Classic Trucks Magazine." The
slalom course is 70-foot

spacing, so it's not really
applicable or comparable to
some of the new car stuff.

But comparing it to some of the
other cars that we have

done over the years, it was
equivalent to our '55 Chevy

that we built, which when we
tested that was comparable to,

like, a C5, C6 Corvette
in the numbers.

And it's pretty phenomenal to
say that something like this

can go out and corner, and
slalom, and break very similar
to American sports car.

MIKE MUSTO: It's just
a fun truck.

I mean, even when you jump
on it, you roll into it.

I like the way that when you
pass people in this thing,

they look at you and they see
this kind of slam truck, and I

think their immediate thought
is, oh my god.

I got a low rider truck on air
bags, which is so not the case
on this thing.

I mean, coilovers up
front and out back.

And the fact that it'll pull,
like, .09 on a skid pad, and

go through a slalom at, like,
65, 68 miles an hour, is
beyond impressive.
It's pretty great.

I mean, it's not the fact that
you're going to do it every

day, but it's the fact that you
know you can do it every

day that makes this truck
fun and exciting.

CRAIG MORRISON: The personal
history, I think, adds

something kind of
special to it.

And then the other cars that
we've done, like the Corvette

that you guys tested, and the
'55 Chevy that was tested as

well, the paint and body work
is so nice on some of those

other cars we built, and the
upholstery is so nice, that we

can't really do what we
did today with it.

Go out and drive it, and park
it in the mud, and run over

rocks, and get it grubby, and
get the wheels this dirty, and
that sort of thing.

And so to have something like
this that you truly can drive

everywhere and at any time
that you want is a really
great and refreshing thing.

MIKE MUSTO: So in trying to
figure out what this truck

really is, we've come
to this conclusion.

This is the 50-year-old yoga
instructor that still looks
great in those pants.

She's got all the right curves,
a little patina around

the edges, which means she knows
exactly what to do to

make you smile every single
time you drive her.

Guys, this was a great day,
great week, great everything

on BIG MUSCLE today, despite
the weather.

So as always, tune in next week
for another great episode

of BIG MUSCLE, right
here on DRIVE.

CRAIG MORRISON: We actually had
two guys come in the booth
that told a great story.

They said, gosh, we were out
watching the auto cross and we

saw this old farm truck out
running around and doing
really well.

Have you guys thought about
doing a project like that?

Because that was just
absolutely bitching.

And I kind of started laughing
and said, well, actually that
truck is ours.
And I was driving it.

comments.author: Ryan Hussey

comments.text:
Beautiful truck, and great build. So glad to see a carbed engine. I'm 
really sick of seeing otherwise great looking vintage cars/trucks with a 
computer controlled fuel injected engine under the hood. My whole 
attraction to vintage vehicles and hot rods is the LACK of that kind of 
thing. I am a mechanic, not a computer technician. ﻿

comments.author: wayne folse

comments.text:
Wow, this is too cool. The Chevy 3100 is my dream classic car/truck that 
I've wanted since I was a little kid. I've always wanted to learn about 
cars to be able to buy, restore and transform one into a hot rod. Possibly 
with a small block if capable, and have the rare full back window for 
better viability and a custom two tone paint job with pin stripes. 

In seeing this beautiful work of art and ingenuity, makes my vision of what 
I'd like to learn and apply to a whole new level. Great job with this 
classic.﻿
